title: How to Create a Ribbon Wrapped Ponytail

steps.headline: Pull your hair back into a ponytail.
steps.description: Slip a hair tie that matches your hair color onto your wrist. Use your hands a brush to gather your hair back into a ponytail. It can be a low, medium, or high ponytail. After you brush out the tangles, apply gel or mousse to create a smooth and sleek ponytail.

steps.headline: Wrap the hair tie around your hair to secure it.
steps.description: Hold your hair with the hand that has the hair tie on it. Use your other hand to slip the hair tie off and wrap it around the base of your ponytail. Depending on the thickness of you hair, you'll probably need to wrap it 2 to 3 times.

steps.headline: Cut a length of ribbon.
steps.description: The longer the ribbon is, the further down your ponytail it will be able to go. The wrapped ponytail that appears on the runway is covered three-fourths of the way by ribbon. You can make yours shorter than that. Plan on cutting the ribbon about 4 times the length of your ponytail. You can use a ribbon that matches your hair color or a bright, interesting color. For something more chic, try suede or velvet.

steps.headline: Place the ribbon under the ponytail.
steps.description: Find the center of the ribbon, and place it under the ponytail, right over the elastic. Pull both ends up towards the ceiling until they are equal length.

steps.headline: Cross the ends over each other.
steps.description: Bring the left ribbon over the top of the ponytail so that it covers the elastic. Pull the right ribbon over the left ribbon, forming a cross. Gently tug on both ribbons to tighten the hold.

steps.headline: Cross the ribbons under the ponytail.
steps.description: Bring the ribbons under the ponytail and cross them, just like you did on the top. Try to get them as close to where the ribbon is as possible, so that there is no gap.

steps.headline: Keep wrapping and crossing the ribbons.
steps.description: Keep the ribbons nice and tight so that they bind your hair and no gaps are visible. For a neater finish, cross the same ribbon over first each time; don't switch up the order. You can keep going until you run out of ribbon, or until your ponytail is covered as far as you'd like. The traditional ribbon-wrapped ponytail is covered three-fourths of the way, but you can cover more or less than that, depending on your personal preference.

steps.headline: Tie the ribbons under the ponytail.
steps.description: Once your ponytail is covered to your liking, bring the ribbons under it one last time. Tie the ribbons together in a tight, double-knot. Trim off any excess ribbon, if necessary.

steps.headline: Pull your hair back into a ponytail.
steps.description: Wrap a hair tie around your wrist first, then pull your hair into a ponytail. You can make it a low ponytail, a mid-height ponytail, or even a high ponytail. Use your hands and a hairbrush to get your hair as smooth as possible. This look works great with curly or wavy hair! The hair tie will be covered by the ribbon, so the color does not matter.

steps.headline: Secure your ponytail with the hair tie.
steps.description: Hold your ponytail with the hand that has the hair tie around it. Use your free hand to pull the hair tie off your wrist and onto the ponytail. Wrap it around your ponytail to secure it. You'll probably need to wrap it two to three times.

steps.headline: Cut a length of wide ribbon.
steps.description: Choose a 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) wide piece of ribbon. You can also cut some pretty fabric into a 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) wide strip. The ribbon needs to be long enough to wrap around the base of your ponytail a few times. The ribbon does not have to be exactly 2 inches (5.08 centimeters). It can be a little narrower/wider.

steps.headline: Place a piece of double-sided tape on one of the ribbon ends.
steps.description: Cut a piece of tape few inches long, and place it lengthwise onto one end of the ribbon. Make sure that you are placing the tape on the wrong (dull) side of the ribbon. If you are using fabric, place it on the wrong side of the fabric. Keeping the tape lengthwise will give your ribbon better grip. For a neater finish, cut another 2-inch (5.08-centimeter) long piece of tape, and place it against the very edge of your ribbon.

steps.headline: Hold the non-taped end over the hair tie.
steps.description: Make sure that the shiny side of the ribbon is sticking out. Also, try to get it as close to your head as possible.

steps.headline: Wrap the ribbon tightly around the hair tie.
steps.description: Hold the end of the ribbon against the hair tie as you make the first wrap. Afterwards, you can left go of the end, and continue wrapping it.

steps.headline: Press the taped end down firmly.
steps.description: As you get towards the end of your ribbon, you will reached the taped part. Press the taped part against the ribbon that is already there and try not to "drag" it. Try to get the end of the ribbon under your ponytail, where it will be out of sight.

steps.headline: Fluff out your ponytail, if desired.
steps.description: The traditional ribbon-wrapped ponytail is nice and sleek, but this one has more of a vintage vibe. Gently pull on your ponytail to give it more volume. Don't pull too hard, however, or the ribbon wrapping will come apart.

steps.headline: Pull your hair into a low ponytail.
steps.description: For a sleek look, apply gel or mousse to your hair after brushing out the tangles. Use your hands and a hairbrush to pull your hair back towards the nape of your neck.

steps.headline: Secure the ponytail with a hair tie.
steps.description: Hold the ponytail with the hand that has the elastic on it. Use your other hand to pull the elastic off and wrap it tightly around the ponytail.

steps.headline: Tie a ribbon to the base of your ponytail.
steps.description: Wrap one end of the ribbon around the base of your ponytail, covering the elastic. Bring both the ribbon and the tail end under the ponytail, and tie them into a tight knot. How long you cut your ribbon depends on how far you want to wrap it. Plan on cutting the ribbon about twice the length of your ponytail. You can use any type of ribbon for this, from velvet to suede to satin.

steps.headline: Gather your ponytail.
steps.description: Grab your ponytail by the base, avoiding the ribbon. Pull your hand downwards, smoothing it. Give it a slight twist to make a thick rope.

steps.headline: Wrap the ribbon around your ponytail in a spiral.
steps.description: Wrap the ribbon tightly, but keep each "row" 1 to 2 inches (2.54 to 5.08 centimeters) apart. You should have something that looks like a spiral. As you make your first wrap, be sure to tuck the tail end of the ribbon under itself.

steps.headline: Keep wrapping your hair until it's covered to your liking.
steps.description: You can cover just a few inches, half of it, three-fourths of it, or even all of it. Just be sure to space the rows evenly.

steps.headline: Secure the end of your wrapped ponytail with another elastic.
steps.description: Hold the end of your ponytail with one hand, including the ribbon. Grab another hair tie that matches your hair color, and wrap it tightly around the end of your ponytail and ribbon. This will hold everything together. For a neater finish, wrap the excess ribbon around the hair tie, then tuck it in under itself.
